title: Test and Item Analysis via Shiny
text: ShinyItemAnalysis R package including functions interactive shiny application psychometric analysis educational tests, psychological assessments, health-related types multi-item measurements, ratings multiple raters. Offered methods include: Exploration total standard scores Analysis correlation structure validity Analysis measurement error reliability Traditional item analysis Item analysis regression models Item analysis IRT models Detection differential item functioning … via add-modules  Number toy datasets available, interactive application also allows users upload analyze data automatically generate PDF HTML reports. ShinyItemAnalysis available online Czech Academy Sciences shinyapps.io. can also downloaded CRAN. Visit web page ShinyItemAnalysis learn !

what: AIBS grant peer review scoring dataset — AIBS
title: AIBS grant peer review scoring dataset — AIBS
text: AIBS dataset (Gallo, 2020) comes scientific peer review facilitated American Institute Biological Sciences (AIBS) biomedical applications intramural collaborative biomedical research program 2014–2017. proposal, three assigned individual reviewers asked provide scores commentary following application criteria: Innovation, Approach/Feasibility, Investigator, Significance (Impact added scored criterion 2014). criteria scored scale 1.0 (best) 5.0 (worst) 0.1 gradation, well overall score (1.0–5.0 0.1 gradation). Asynchronous discussion allowed, although scores changed post-discussion. data includes reviewers' self-reported expertise scores (1/2/3, 1 high expertise) relative proposal reviewed, reviewer / principal investigator demographics. total 72 applications ("Standard" "Pilot") reviewed 3 review cycles. success rate 34–38 %. Application scores indicate application falls among practically possible applications comparison ideal standard quality perfect application. dataset used Erosheva et al. (2021a) demonstrate issues inter-rater reliability case restricted samples. details, see Erosheva et al. (2021b).

title: AIBS grant peer review scoring dataset — AIBS
AIBS grant peer review scoring dataset — AIBS

PIRank PI's rank; "3" full professor, "1" assistant professor. PIDegree PI's degree; "1" PhD, "2" MD, "3" PhD/MD. Innovation Innovation score. Approach Approach score. Investig Investigator score. Signif Significance score. Impact Impact score. Score Scientific merit (overall) score. ScoreAvg Average three overall scores three different reviewers. ScoreAvgAdj Average three overall scores three different reviewers, increased multiple 0.001 worst score. ScoreRank Project rank calculated based ScoreAvg. ScoreRankAdj Project rank calculated based ScoreAvgAdj. RevID Reviewer's ID. RevExp Reviewer's experience. RevInst Reviewer's institution; "1" academia, "2" government. RevGender Reviewer's gender; "1" females, "2" males. RevRank Reviewer's rank; "3" full professor, "1" assistant professor. RevDegree Reviewer's degree; "1" PhD, "2" MD, "3" PhD/MD. what: Plot difficulties and discriminations/item validity — DDplot
title: Plot difficulties and discriminations/item validity — DDplot
text: Plots difficulty (generalized) discrimination criterion validity items multi-item measurement test using ggplot2 package. Difficulty discrimination/validity indices plotted item, items ordered difficulty.

title: Plot difficulties and discriminations/item validity — DDplot
code: DDplot(   Data,   item.names,   discrim = "ULI",   k = 3,   l = 1,   u = 3,   maxscore,   minscore,   bin = FALSE,   cutscore,   average.score = FALSE,   thr = 0.2,   criterion = "none",   val_type = "simple",   data )

title: Plot difficulties and discriminations/item validity — DDplot
text: Data numeric: binary ordinal data matrix data.frame rows represent examinee answers (1 correct, 0 incorrect, ordinal item scores) columns correspond items. item.names character: names items. specified, names Data columns used. discrim character: type discrimination index calculated. Possible values "ULI" (default), "RIT", "RIR", "none". See Details. k numeric: number groups data may divided total score estimate discrimination using discrim = "ULI". Default value 3.  See Details. l numeric: lower group. Default value 1. See Details. u numeric: upper group. Default value 3. See Details. maxscore numeric: maximal scores items. single number provided, maximal score used items. missing, vector achieved maximal scores calculated used calculations. minscore numeric: minimal scores items. single number provided, maximal score used items. missing, vector achieved maximal scores calculated used calculations. bin logical: ordinal data binarized? Default value FALSE. case bin = TRUE, values Data equal greater cutscore marked 1 values lower cutscore marked 0. cutscore numeric: cut-score used binarize Data. numeric, cut-score used items. missing, vector maximal scores used calculations. average.score logical: average score item displayed instead difficulty? Default value FALSE. See Details. thr numeric: value discrimination threshold. Default value 0.2. thr = NULL, horizontal line displayed plot. criterion numeric logical vector: values criterion. supplied, disrim argument ignored item-criterion correlation (validity) displayed instead. Default value "none". val_type character: criterion validity measure. Possible values "simple" (correlation item score validity criterion; default) "index" (item validity index calculated cor(item, criterion) * sqrt(((N - 1) / N) * var(item)), N number respondents, see Allen & Yen, 1979, Ch. 6.4, details). argument ignored user supply criterion. data deprecated. Use argument Data instead.

title: Plot difficulties and discriminations/item validity — DDplot
text: Discrimination calculated using method specified discrim. Default option "ULI" calculates difference ratio correct answers upper lower third students. "RIT" index calculates correlation item score test total score. "RIR" index calculates correlation item score total score rest items. option "none", difficulty displayed. "ULI" index can generalized using arguments k, l u. Generalized ULI discrimination computed follows: function takes data individuals, computes total test score divides individuals k groups. lower upper group determined l u parameters, .e.  l-th u-th group ordering defined increasing total score. ordinal data, difficulty defined relative score:   Minimal score can specified minscore, maximal score can specified maxscore. Average score items can displayed argument average.score = TRUE. Note binary data difficulty estimate average score item. Note correlations estimated using Pearson correlation coefficient.

title: Plot difficulties and discriminations/item validity — DDplot

Semi-real-time analyses item characteristics medical school admission tests. : Proceedings 2017 Federated Conference Computer Science Information Systems.

title: Plot difficulties and discriminations/item validity — DDplot
code: # binary dataset dataBin <- dataMedical[, 1:100] # ordinal dataset dataOrd <- dataMedicalgraded[, 1:100]  # DDplot of binary dataset DDplot(dataBin)  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # DDplot of binary dataset without threshold DDplot(dataBin, thr = NULL) # compared to DDplot using ordinal dataset and 'bin = TRUE' DDplot(dataOrd, bin = TRUE) # compared to binarized dataset using bin = TRUE and cut-score equal to 3 DDplot(dataOrd, bin = TRUE, cutscore = 3)  # DDplot of binary data using generalized ULI # discrimination based on 5 groups, comparing 4th and 5th # threshold lowered to 0.1 DDplot(dataBin, k = 5, l = 4, u = 5, thr = 0.1)  # DDplot of ordinal dataset using ULI DDplot(dataOrd) # DDplot of ordinal dataset using generalized ULI # discrimination based on 5 groups, comparing 4th and 5th # threshold lowered to 0.1 DDplot(dataOrd, k = 5, l = 4, u = 5, thr = 0.1) # DDplot of ordinal dataset using RIT DDplot(dataOrd, discrim = "RIT") # DDplot of ordinal dataset using RIR DDplot(dataOrd, discrim = "RIR") # DDplot of ordinal dataset displaying only difficulty DDplot(dataBin, discrim = "none")  # DDplot of ordinal dataset displaying difficulty estimates DDplot(dataOrd) # DDplot of ordinal dataset displaying average item scores DDplot(dataOrd, average.score = TRUE)  # item difficulty / criterion validity plot for data with criterion data(GMAT, package = "difNLR") DDplot(GMAT[, 1:20], criterion = GMAT$criterion, val_type = "simple") } # }

title: Distractor analysis — DistractorAnalysis
text: Data character: data matrix data.frame rows representing unscored item responses multiple-choice test columns corresponding items. key character: answer key items. key must vector length ncol(Data). case provided, criterion needs specified. item numeric character: either character "" apply items (default), vector item names (column names Data), item identifiers (integers specifying column number). p.table logical: function return proportions? FALSE (default), counts returned. num.groups numeric: number groups respondents split. criterion numeric: numeric vector. provided, total score calculated distractor analysis performed based . crit.discrete logical: criterion discrete? Default value FALSE. See details. cut.points numeric: numeric vector specifying cut points criterion. See details. data deprecated. Use argument Data instead. matching deprecated. Use argument criterion instead. match.discrete deprecated. Use argument crit.discrete instead.

title: Distractor analysis — DistractorAnalysis
text: function adapted version distractor.analysis() function CTT package. case criterion provided, scores calculated using item Data key. respondents default split num.groups-quantiles number (proportion) respondents quantile reported respect answers. case criterion discrete (crit.discrete = TRUE), criterion split based unique levels. cut points can specified via cut.points argument.

text: Function estimating reliability intra-class correlation complete range-restricted sample.

title: Range-restricted reliability with intra-class correlation — ICCrestricted
code: ICCrestricted(   Data,   case,   var,   rank = NULL,   dir = "top",   sel = 1,   nsim = 100,   ci = 0.95,   seed = NULL )

title: Range-restricted reliability with intra-class correlation — ICCrestricted
text: Data matrix data.frame includes variables describing ID ratees (specified case), ratings (specified var), (optionally) rank ratees (specified rank). case character: name variable Data ID ratee (subject object evaluated, respondent, proposal, patient, applicant etc.) var character: name variable Data ratings/scores. rank numeric: vector ranks ratees. provided, rank ratee calculated based average rating based var variable. dir character: direction range-restriction, available options "top" (default) "bottom". Can unambiguous abbreviation (.e., "t" "b"). sel numeric: selected number (given > 1) percentage (given <= 1) ratees. Default value 1 (complete dataset). nsim numeric: number simulations bootstrap confidence interval. Default value 100. ci numeric: confidence interval. Default value 0.95. seed seed simulations. Default value NULL, random seed. See lme4::bootMer() detail.

title: Range-restricted reliability with intra-class correlation — ICCrestricted
text: data.frame following columns: n_sel number ratees selected/subsetted. prop_sel proportion ratees selected. dir direction range-restriction. NA range effectively restricted (100% used). VarID variance due ratee, "true variance", -group variance. VarResid residual variance. VarTotal total variance. ICC1 single-rater inter-rater reliability. ICC1_LCI lower bound confidence interval ICC1. ICC1_UCI upper bound confidence interval ICC1. ICC3 multiple-rater inter-rater reliability. ICC3_LCI lower bound confidence interval ICC3. ICC3_UCI upper bound confidence interval ICC3.

what: Compute traditional item analysis indices — ItemAnalysis
title: Compute traditional item analysis indices — ItemAnalysis
text: Computes various traditional item analysis indices including difficulty, discrimination item validity. ordinal items, function returns scaled values indices. See details .

title: Compute traditional item analysis indices — ItemAnalysis
code: ItemAnalysis(   Data,   minscore = NULL,   maxscore = NULL,   cutscore = NULL,   criterion = NULL,   k = NULL,   l = NULL,   u = NULL,   bin = "deprecated" )

title: Compute traditional item analysis indices — ItemAnalysis
text: Data matrix data.frame items examined. Rows represent respondents, columns represent items. minscore, maxscore integer, theoretical minimal/maximal score. provided, computed observed data. Automatically recycled number columns data. cutscore integer provided, input data binarized accordingly. Automatically recycled number columns data. criterion vector criterion values. k, l, u Arguments passed gDiscrim(). Provide want compute generalized upper-lower index along standard ULI (using k = 3, l = 1, u = 3), provided default. bin deprecated, use cutscore instead. See Details.

title: Compute traditional item analysis indices — ItemAnalysis
text: data.frame following columns: Difficulty average score item divided range. Mean average item score. SD standard deviation item score. Cut.score cut-score specified cutscore. obs.min observed minimal score. Min.score minimal score specified minscore; provided, observed minimal score. obs.max observed maximal score. Max.score maximal score specified maxscore; provided, observed maximal score. Prop.max.score proportion maximal scores. RIT item-total correlation (correlation item score overall test score). RIR item-rest correlation (correlation item score overall test score without given item). ULI upper-lower index using standard parameters (3 groups, comparing 1st 3rd). Corr.criterion correlation item score criterion criterion. gULI generalized ULI. NA arguments k, l, u provided. Alpha.drop Cronbach's alpha without given item. Index.rel Gulliksen's (1950) item reliability index. Index.val Gulliksen's (1950) item validity index. Perc.miss Percentage missed responses particular item. Perc.nr Percentage respondents reached item subsequent ones, see recode_nr() details.

title: Compute traditional item analysis indices — ItemAnalysis
text: calculation generalized ULI index, possible specify custom number groups k, two groups l u compared. ordinal items, difficulty calculated difference average score divided range (maximal possible score maxscore minus minimal possible score minscore). cutscore provided, item analysis conducted binarized data; values greater equal cut-score set 1, values set 0. minscore maxscore arguments ingored set 0 1, respectively.

what: Dichotomous dataset of learning to learn test — LearningToLearn
title: Dichotomous dataset of learning to learn test — LearningToLearn
text: LearningToLearn real longitudinal dataset used Martinkova et al (2020) study, demonstrating differential item functioning change (DIF-C) Learning Learn (LtL) test. Among variables, primarily contains binary-coded responses 782 subjects (mostly) multiple-choice test consisting 41 items within 7 subscales (see Format details). respondent tested twice total – first time Grade 6 second time Grade 9. importantly, school track (variable track_01 track) available, 391 students attending basic school (BS) 391 pursuing selective academic school (). dataset created using propensity score matching algorithm achieve similar characteristics tracks (see References details). simplify work LtL dataset, provide computed total scores well 7 subscores, Grade 6 Grade 9. dataset also includes change variables item (see Format details) detailed DIF-C analysis using multinomial regression model.

title: Dichotomous dataset of learning to learn test — LearningToLearn
Dichotomous dataset of learning to learn test — LearningToLearn
text: LearningToLearn data frame consists 782 observations following 141 variables: track_01 Dichotomously scored school track, "1" denotes selective academic school one. track School track, "" represents selective academic school track, "BS" stands basic school track. score_6 & score_9 Total test score value obtained summing 41 items LtL, number denotes Grade respondent taking time testing. score_6_subtest1–score_6_subtest7 Scores respective cognitive subtest (1–7) LtL Grade 6. score_9_subtest1–score_9_subtest7 Scores respective cognitive subtest (1–7) LtL Grade 9. Item1A_6–Item7F_6 Dichotomously coded 41 individual items obtained Grade 6, "1" represents correct answer particular item. Item1A_9–Item7F_9 Dichotomously coded 41 individual items obtained Grade 9, "1" represents correct answer particular item. Item1A_changes–Item7F_changes Change patterns possible values: student responded correctly neither Grade 6 Grade 9 (improve, "00") student responded correctly Grade 6 Grade 9 (deteriorated, "10") student respond correctly Grade 6 responded correctly Grade 9 (improved, "01"), student responded correctly grades (deteriorate, "11")

title: Dichotomous dataset of learning to learn test — LearningToLearn

what: NIH grant peer review scoring dataset — NIH
title: NIH grant peer review scoring dataset — NIH
text: NIH dataset (Erosheva et al., 2020a) sampled full set 54,740 R01 applications submitted black white principal investigators (PIs) reviewed Center Scientific Review (CSR) National Institutes Health (NIH) council years 2014–2016. contains original random sample white applicants generated Erosheva et al. (2020b) sample 46 black applicants generated obtain ratio white black applicants original sample (details, see Erosheva et al., 2021a). dataset used Erosheva et al. (2021b) demonstrate issues inter-rater reliability case restricted samples. available variables include preliminary criterion scores Significance, Investigator, Innovation, Approach, Environment preliminary Overall Impact Score. criteria overall score scored integer scale 1 (best) 9 (worst). Besides preliminary criteria Overall Impact Scores, data include applicant race, structural covariates (PI ID, application ID, reviewer ID, administering institute, IRG, SRG), matching variables – gender, ethnicity (Hispanic/Latino ), career stage, type academic degree, institution prestige (reflected NIH funding bin), area science (reflected IRG handling application), application type (new renewal) status (amended ) – well final overall score. addition, file includes study group ID variable refers Matched Random subsets used original study.

what: ShinyItemAnalysis: Test and Item Analysis via Shiny — ShinyItemAnalysis-package
title: ShinyItemAnalysis: Test and Item Analysis via Shiny — ShinyItemAnalysis-package
text: ShinyItemAnalysis package contains interactive Shiny application psychometric analysis educational tests, psychological assessments, health-related types multi-item measurements, ratings multiple raters, can accessed using function startShinyItemAnalysis(). shiny application covers broad range psychometric methods offers data examples, model equations, parameter estimates, interpretation results, together selected R code, therefore suitable teaching psychometric concepts R. also allows users upload analyze data automatically generate analysis reports PDF HTML. Besides, package provides functions test item analysis within classical test theory framework (e.g., functions gDiscrim(), ItemAnalysis(), DistractorAnalysis(), DDplot()), using various regression models (e.g., plotCumulative(), plotAdjacent(), plotMultinomial(), plotDIFLogistic()), IRT framework (e.g., ggWrightMap(), plotDIFirt()). Package also contains several demonstration datasets including HCI dataset book Martinkova Hladka (2023), paper Martinkova Drabinova (2018).

title: ShinyItemAnalysis: Test and Item Analysis via Shiny — ShinyItemAnalysis-package

SIA_MODULES_DEBUG: Setting TRUE provides verbose description SIA modules-related processes. Useful debugging purposes. SIA_MODULES_FORCE_GUI_INSTALLATION: app running shiny-server, interactive module installation within app allowed default. Setting variable TRUE override restriction enable module installation app.

title: Conduct Parallel Analysis — fa_parallel
text: Horn proposed solution problem optimal factor number identification using approach based Monte Carlo simulation. First, several (20 default) zero-factor p-variate normal distributions (p number columns) obtained, p × p correlation matrices computed . Eigenvalues matrix calculated order get eigenvalues sampling distribution simulated variable. Traditionally, Horn obtains average sampling distribution averages used threshold compared eigenvalues original, real data. However, usage mean later disputed Buja & Eyuboglu (1992), 95th percentile eigenvalues sampling distribution suggested accurate threshold. , recent method used default function.

title: Compute generalized item discrimination — gDiscrim
text: function computes total test scores respondents divides respondents k groups. lower upper groups determined l u parameters, .e., l-th u-th group ordering defined increasing total score. ordinal items, difficulty calculated difference average score divided range (maximal possible score maxscore minus minimal possible score minscore given item). Discrimination calculated difference difficulty upper lower group.

text: Adela Hladka  Institute Computer Science Czech Academy Sciences hladka@cs.cas.cz Lubomir Stepanek  Institute Computer Science Czech Academy Sciences Jana Vorlickova  Institute Computer Science Czech Academy Sciences Patricia Martinkova  Institute Computer Science Czech Academy Sciences martinkova@cs.cas.cz Jan Netik  Institute Computer Science Czech Academy Sciences netik@cs.cas.cz

title: Compute generalized item discrimination — gDiscrim
code: # binary dataset dataBin <- dataMedical[, 1:100] # ordinal dataset dataOrd <- dataMedicalgraded[, 1:100]  # ULI for the first 5 items of binary dataset # compare to psychometric::discrim(dataBin) gDiscrim(dataBin)[1:5] #>     X2001     X2002     X2003     X2004     X2005  #> 0.1614213 0.1035596 0.4885943 0.3868710 0.3318481  # generalized ULI using 5 groups, compare 4th and 5th for binary dataset gDiscrim(dataBin, k = 5, l = 4, u = 5)[1:5] #>     X2001     X2002     X2003     X2004     X2005  #> 0.1018641 0.1121100 0.1987705 0.2145360 0.1099617   # ULI for first 5 items for ordinal dataset gDiscrim(dataOrd)[1:5] #>      X2001      X2002      X2003      X2004      X2005  #> 0.09572166 0.16840558 0.31334624 0.19898637 0.17202272  # generalized ULI using 5 groups, compare 4th and 5th for binary dataset gDiscrim(dataOrd, k = 5, l = 4, u = 5)[1:5] #>      X2001      X2002      X2003      X2004      X2005  #> 0.03969971 0.12682360 0.08110496 0.09022718 0.05604466  # maximum (4) and minimum (0) score are same for all items gDiscrim(dataOrd, k = 5, l = 4, u = 5, maxscore = 4, minscore = 0)[1:5] #>      X2001      X2002      X2003      X2004      X2005  #> 0.03969971 0.12682360 0.08110496 0.09022718 0.05604466

what: Plot person-item map (Wright map) using ggplot2 — ggWrightMap
title: Plot person-item map (Wright map) using ggplot2 — ggWrightMap
text: function allows generate Wright map (also called person-item map) using ggplot() function ggplot2 package. Wright map used jointly display histogram abilities (measured trait) item difficulty parameters. Function takes pre-estimated parameter estimates, obtained IRT model.

title: Plot person-item map (Wright map) using ggplot2 — ggWrightMap
code: ggWrightMap(   theta,   b,   binwidth = 0.5,   color = "blue",   size = 15,   item.names,   ylab.theta = "Respondent latent trait",   ylab.b = "Item difficulty",   rel_widths = c(1, 1) )

title: Plot person-item map (Wright map) using ggplot2 — ggWrightMap
text: theta numeric: vector ability estimates. b numeric: vector difficulty estimates. binwidth numeric: width bins histogram. color character: color histogram. size text size pts. item.names names items displayed. ylab.theta character: description y-axis histogram. ylab.b character: description y-axis plot difficulty estimates. rel_widths numeric: vector length 2 specifying ratio "facet's" widths.

title: Turn nominal (factor) data to integers, keep original levels with a key of correct responses alongside — nominal_to_int
text: Fitting nominal model using mirt::mirt() package requires dataset consist integers, arbitrarily representing response categories. can convert dataset integers case. hand, BLIS model (thus also BLIRT parametrization) requires information correct item response category. top , information leveraged fitting mirt model conserves "directionality" estimated latent ability (using model definition obtain_nrm_def()). cases, recommended use nominal_to_int() (note fit_blis() blis() internally). Note also fitted BLIS model (class BlisClass) stores original levels correct answer key orig_levels slot, accessible user via get_orig_levels().

what: Obtain model definition for mirt's nominal model taking in account the key of correct answers — obtain_nrm_def
title: Obtain model definition for mirt's nominal model taking in account the key of correct answers — obtain_nrm_def
text: Standard mirt model itemtype = "nominal" puts identification constrains item response category slopes \(ak_0 = 0\) \(ak_{(K-1)} = (K - 1)\), freely estimating rest. nominal item responses unordered definition, often case one item response categories correct respondents endorsing category "naturally" possess higher latent ability. Use function obtain model definition correct response category \(k_c\) item \(\) \(K\) possible response categories translates constrains \(ak_{k_c} = (K - 1)\) \(ak_{k_{d1}} = 0\), \(k_{d1}\) first incorrect response category (.e. first distractor).

title: Plot item characteristic curve of DIF IRT model — plotDIFirt
text: function plots characteristic curve DIF IRT model. parameters matrix number rows equal twice number items data set. first J rows refer item parameter estimates reference group, last J ones correspond items focal group. number columns depends selected IRT model: 2 1PL model, 5 2PL model, 6 constrained 3PL model 9 unconstrained 3PL model. columns irtParam() follow structure output itemParEst(), difLord() difRaju() command difR package. Two possible type test statistics can visualized - "Lord" gives characteristic curves, "Raju" also highlights area curves. default option "", characteristic curves plotted.

Default value FALSE. cut.points numeric: numeric vector specifying cut points criterion. data deprecated. Use argument Data instead. matching deprecated. title: Plot item distractor analysis — plotDistractorAnalysis
code: Data <- dataMedicaltest[, 1:100] DataBin <- dataMedical[, 1:100] key <- dataMedicalkey  # distractor plot for items 48, 57 and 32 displaying distractors only # correct answer B does not function well: plotDistractorAnalysis(Data, key, item = 48, multiple.answers = FALSE) #> $X2048  #>   # all options function well, thus the whole item discriminates well: plotDistractorAnalysis(Data, key, item = 57, multiple.answers = FALSE) #> $X48  #>   # functions well, thus the whole item discriminates well: plotDistractorAnalysis(Data, key, item = 32, multiple.answers = FALSE) #> $X2032  #>   if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # distractor plot for items 48, 57 and 32 displaying all combinations plotDistractorAnalysis(Data, key, item = c(48, 57, 32))  # distractor plot for item 57 with all combinations and 6 groups plotDistractorAnalysis(Data, key, item = 57, num.group = 6)  # distractor plot for item 57 using specified criterion and key option criterion <- round(rowSums(DataBin), -1) plotDistractorAnalysis(Data, key, item = 57, criterion = criterion) # distractor plot for item 57 using specified criterion without key option plotDistractorAnalysis(Data, item = 57, criterion = criterion)  # distractor plot for item 57 using discrete criterion plotDistractorAnalysis(Data, key,   item = 57, criterion = criterion,   crit.discrete = TRUE )  # distractor plot for item 57 using groups specified by cut.points plotDistractorAnalysis(Data, key, item = 57, cut.points = seq(10, 96, 10)) } # }

title: Compute and plot an item correlation matrix — plot_corr
text: Computes visualizes item correlation matrix (also known heatmap), offering several correlation "types" optional clustering (possible cluster outlining). function relies ggplot2::ggplot(), providing high customisability using "grammar graphics" (see examples ).

title: Compute and plot an item correlation matrix — plot_corr
code: plot_corr(   Data,   cor = c("polychoric", "tetrachoric", "pearson", "spearman", "none"),   clust_method = "none",   n_clust = 0L,   shape = c("circle", "square"),   labels = FALSE,   labels_size = 3,   line_size = 0.5,   line_col = "black",   line_alpha = 1,   fill = NA,   fill_alpha = NA,   ... )

title: Compute and plot an item correlation matrix — plot_corr
text: Data matrix, data.frame tibble: either data.frame scored items (columns, one observation per row), correlation matrix. cor character: correlation "type" used correlation matrix computation; available options polychoric, tetrachoric, pearson, spearman, none (case provide correlation matrix Data). clust_method character: optional clustering method, available options : ward.D, ward.D2, single, complete, average (= UPGMA), mcquitty (= WPGMA), median (= WPGMC), centroid (= UPGMC) none (clustering disabled). See hclust() detailed description available options. n_clust integer: number clusters want outlined. set zero (default), cluster outlined, items still get sorted according clust_method (set none). shape character: tile appearance; either circle (default) map correlation coefficient circle size color, square draw square-shaped tiles shade denoting coefficient magnitude. can use unambiguous abbreviation two. labels logical: TRUE, correlation coefficients plotted onto tiles. labels_size numeric: label size points (pts). line_size numeric: cluster outline width. line_col character: color outline, either HEX code (e.g. "#123456"), one R's standard colors (see colors()). line_alpha numeric 0-1: opacity outline. fill character: color used fill outlined clusters. fill_alpha numeric 0–1: opacity fill color. ... Arguments passed psych::polychoric correct Correction value use correct continuity case zero entry cell tetrachoric, polychoric, polybi, mixed.cor.  See examples effect correcting versus correcting continuity. smooth TRUE tetrachoric/polychoric matrix positive definite, apply simple smoothing algorithm using cor.smooth global finding pairwise correlations, use global values tau parameter (somewhat faster), local values (global=FALSE)?  local option equivalent polycor solution, one correlation time. global=TRUE borrows information one item pair pairs using item's frequencies.   make difference presence lots missing data. small sample sizes global=FALSE correct=TRUE, function fail (yet underdetermined reasons. weight vector length number observations specifies weights apply case.  NULL case equivalent weights 1 cases. std.err std.err=FALSE report standard errors (faster)  deprecated progress Show progress bar ( multicores) ML ML=FALSE  quick two step procedure, ML=TRUE, longer maximum likelihood — slow! Deprecated delete Cases variance deleted warning proceeding. max.cat maximum number categories bother polychoric.

title: Compute and plot an item correlation matrix — plot_corr
text: Correlation heatmap displays selected type correlations items. color tiles indicates much way items correlated – red color means positive correlation blue color means negative correlation. Correlation heatmap can reordered using hierarchical clustering method specified clust_method argument. desired number clusters (argument n_clust) zero clustering demanded, rectangles outlining found clusters drawn.

title: Compute and plot an item correlation matrix — plot_corr

title: Compute and plot an item correlation matrix — plot_corr
code: # use first 20 columns from HCI dataset (the remainder are not items) HCI <- HCI[, 1:20]  # use Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient for matrix computation plot_corr(HCI, cor = "pearson")   if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # use tetrachoric correlation and reorder the resulting heatmap # using Ward's method HCI |> plot_corr(cor = "tetrachoric", clust_method = "ward.D")  # outline 3 Ward's clusters with bold yellow line and add labels HCI |>   plot_corr(     n_clust = 3, clust_method = "ward.D2", line_col = "yellow",     line_size = 1.5, labels = TRUE   )  # add title and position the legend below the plot library(ggplot2) HCI |>   plot_corr(n_clust = 3) +   ggtitle("HCI heatmap") +   theme(legend.position = "bottom")  # mimic the look of corrplot package plot_corr(HCI, cor = "polychoric", clust_method = "complete", shape = "square") +   scale_fill_gradient2(     limits = c(-.1, 1),     breaks = seq(-.1, 1, length.out = 12),     guide = guide_colorbar(       barheight = .8, barwidth = .0275,       default.unit = "npc",       title = NULL, frame.colour = "black", ticks.colour = "black"     )   ) +   theme(axis.text = element_text(colour = "red", size = 12)) } # }
